An unconventional and compassionate guide to becoming an early bird

I thought I was destined to be a night owl forever.

Iâ€™m no stranger to reading about the benefits of waking up early or having the same sleeping routine â€” all of us have probably read this at some point in our lives. Iâ€™m in my final semester of university, so the past few years of my life have been absolute chaos. I have classes some days, work other days, and have free time on especially rare days. Having a routine seemed impossible.

But a few months ago, I started reading Haruki Murakamiâ€™s novels. My favorite is Norwegian Wood. Inspired by Murakamiâ€™s fascinating prose, I researched him a little.

I found this gem in a 2004 interview he did:

When Iâ€™m in writing mode for a novel, I get up at 4 a.m. and work for five to six hours. In the afternoon, I run for ten kilometers or swim for fifteen hundred meters (or do both), then I read a bit and listen to some music. I go to bed at 9 p.m.

I keep to this routine every day without variation. The repetition itself becomes the important thing; itâ€™s a form of mesmerism. I mesmerize myself to reach a deeper state of mind.

But to hold to such repetition for so long â€” six months to a year â€” requires a good amount of mental and physical strength. In that sense, writing a long novel is like survival training. Physical strength is as necessary as artistic sensitivity.

Thereâ€™s something about the way Murakami talks about his routine that moved me. This part, in particular, stood out to me:

The repetition itself becomes the important thing; itâ€™s a form of mesmerism.

Mesmerism has been a part of my life since I was a child; itâ€™s the sense I have every time I establish a new habit. I mesmerized myself as a child to brush my teeth every day in the morning. As an adult, Iâ€™ve mesmerized myself to be healthy by exercising regularly. Iâ€™ve mesmerized myself to reflect on my life by adding a journaling routine.

A surge of motivation struck me, knowing I had done a similar task in the past. I could become an early bird by mesmerizing myself.

For the past 3 months, Iâ€™ve successfully transitioned into being an early bird. I go to sleep at 9 p.m. on average 6-7 nights a week. I currently wake up between 5â€“5:30 a.m. naturally.

I might continue experimenting with waking up even earlier, but Iâ€™m happy with my current routine and donâ€™t want to put too much pressure on myself. After all, itâ€™s healthy to get 8 hours of sleep, isnâ€™t it?

Iâ€™ve tried to become an early bird many times in my life and this is the first time it has actually worked. Hereâ€™s what this process of â€œmesmerizingâ€ myself looked likeâ€”and also a few words about what doesnâ€™t work.

What really worked was more gentle than you might expect. Consider this, then, a compassionate guide to waking up early.

# ğŸŒŸ Clarify Your Purpose for Waking Up Early

Waking up before everyone else is tough. If you donâ€™t have a reason to do it, you wonâ€™t do it.

I donâ€™t just mean purpose in the sense that you want to wake up to do something. Of course, youâ€™re going to wake up early to do something (probably productive). But you need a purpose that extends past a basic task.

Iâ€™m about to graduate from university and Iâ€™m about to enter arguably the most important years of my life â€” years where Iâ€™ll have both money and freedom. If I ever want a chance at escaping at the 9â€“5, I have to do something now. Working in the morning is easier than working at night, so I need to set up my habits now so I can be living that life later.

You might already have a purpose, but if you donâ€™t, try running a 5 Whys analysis (otherwise known as root cause analysis).

To do the 5 Whys:

  1. Form a problem statement.
  2. Ask the question: â€œWhy is/are/does [your problem statement]?â€. Use your answer as the next problem statement.
  3. Keep asking â€œwhyâ€ until youâ€™ve asked it five or more times.

Example:

I want to wake up at 5 a.m. every day.

Why do you want to wake up at 5 a.m. every day?

I want more time to be productive.

Why do you want to be more productive?

I want to practice writing.

Why do you want to practice writing?

I want to write books.

Why do you want to write books?

I want to have a career doing something creative.

Why do you want to have a career doing something creative?

I imagine it to be the most fulfilling thing someone can do in their career.

Starting with a smaller problem and going deep to find the root cause helps you gain a better understanding of what you really want. Itâ€™ll help you understand if waking up is part of the solution to your problem.

Waking up early gives you a few hours every day in the morning where nobody else is going to disturb you. Thatâ€™s all it is for most of us. For me, though, thatâ€™s an important part of my solution to escaping a 9â€“5 rut and doing work I love.

# ğŸ’ª Understand What You Gain and Lose

When I first tried to become an early riser, I didnâ€™t consider what I have to give up. I failed because I wasnâ€™t willing to give up the things I enjoyed, like my weekday social life. I would go out, say Iâ€™d wake up early despite getting home late, and ultimately wake up late.

If you accept what you lose upfront, you wonâ€™t keep trying to hold onto it when itâ€™s gone.

But letâ€™s be optimistic and start with what youâ€™ll gain.

# What you gain

Being an early bird means you get a few hours every day to do whatever you want. Itâ€™s likely nobody else will be awake to disturb you. You can paint, start a business, write â€” anything you want.

Your prefrontal cortex is most active right after waking up, making it optimal for creativity. Iâ€™ve noticed I write much faster in the morning than at any other time in the day. Looking at the habits of famous writers, a lot of them have figured it out too (most authors write in the morning).

Itâ€™s a big win: a few hours of solitude with your most creative self.

# What you lose

Thereâ€™s no free lunch. Waking up early doesnâ€™t give you extra time. It takes off time you would otherwise have at night â€” unless you sleep less, which is a bad idea. If you sleep less, you either wonâ€™t be able to wake up early and become a night owl again, or youâ€™ll be sleep-deprived and unproductive throughout the day.

In reality, I lost time since I started waking up early. I used to sleep for 6 hours and wake up from the urgency to get up and get to work. I canâ€™t do that when Iâ€™m waking up early because thereâ€™s no urgency for me to get out of bed; Iâ€™m weak. So I sleep for 8 hours. Otherwise, the temptation to stay in bed would be too much.

Iâ€™ve lost around 2 hours every dayâ€”but I feel rested throughout the day.

# Running out of time

I finish work at 5 p.m. (haha, 9â€“5). That means I have 4 hours after work before I sleep. But there are a few things I need to do within that time:

  • Commute (1 hour)
  • Cook and eat (1 hour)
  • Exercise (1 hour)
  • Wind down (1 hour)

That adds up to 4 hours. Thereâ€™s no time left to do anything else. Of course, these activities donâ€™t always take an hour each, but you get the point. Winding down is especially important for me. I tried a lot of ways to get around it, but I ended up not being able to sleep.

To keep my sanity, I have dinner with friends on days I donâ€™t exercise. Still, thereâ€™s a limited time I can spend with them (around 2 hours).

It feels like Iâ€™m living in a box, but I canâ€™t say itâ€™s all been bad. Being able to keep up this habit makes me feel eccentric and in some way, special.

I used to watch the life of bodybuilders and wonder how they do it; all they do is eat, train and sleep. They donâ€™t do anything else.

Now I understand them. Thereâ€™s a sense of purpose that comes with living in a box. You know youâ€™re disciplining yourself for a goal.

# Give yourself one day off per week

Iâ€™ve found that if I mess up my sleep schedule one day a week, I can still maintain it throughout the week. I tried sleeping late two or three days a week â€” it didnâ€™t work. But one seems to be okay.

I love going out at night, so Iâ€™ve given myself one day a week (usually Friday) to hang out with friends for longer.

If this is something you need to do to wake up early, I suggest you set rules for it, too. Youâ€™re less likely to fail with disciplined chaos than pure chaos. Give yourself one day a week where youâ€™re allowed to break the rules to mitigate what you feel you are losing.

# Compare the benefits with the cost

Ask yourself these two questions:

  • What will I gain with the extra time in the morning?
  • What will I lose with the lost time at night?

Then ask yourself: â€œDo the benefits outweigh the costs?â€

If they donâ€™t, then thereâ€™s probably no point in waking up early. If they do, there are a few things that helped me thatâ€™ll probably help you.

# ğŸ˜´ Focus on Sleeping Time

When I told myself I was going to wake up at 5 a.m. no matter what, I failed. Iâ€™d do it if I slept too late. Iâ€™d do it if I stayed out late at night. Iâ€™d do it if I stayed up studying.

This didnâ€™t work. I donâ€™t know what I was trying to do by trying to cheat the system, thinking my willpower was enough.

This might work for people who have this habit already. But if youâ€™re starting out, focus on one thing: sleeping time.

# Get enough sleep

A common mistake people make is thinking they can sleep the same amount as they usually do. For example, I only slept for 6 hours before, so I thought I could sleep for 6 hours and still wake up early. This doesnâ€™t work because you end up sleeping in; itâ€™s unlikely you have any willpower when itâ€™s pitch black outside.

For the best chances at waking up early, set a goal for 8 hours of sleep. I want to wake up at 5 a.m., so my sleeping time is 9 p.m. (8 hours before).

# Sleep more than needed (when you start)

When I started, I didnâ€™t set my alarm at 5 a.m. I set no alarm at all. With drastic changes to your sleeping schedule, youâ€™re going to need some time to adjust. You initially need more sleep.

You have the rest of your life to wake up early. Spend some time now getting the habit into your routine. This is a marathon, not a sprint.

Waking up early means waking up when itâ€™s still dark. Give your body some time to adjust to the darkness. It took me about a week; it might be longer or shorter for you.

I naturally woke up earlier and earlier every day. Now I can successfully wake up at 5 a.m. every day.

# ğŸŒ³ Donâ€™t Try to Change Everything

You canâ€™t introduce too much change to your life at once. Changing your sleeping pattern is a big change. I know you want to wake up and do something productive right away. You want to do all the amazing things you couldnâ€™t do before.

Be patient. If you donâ€™t, youâ€™re not going to be able to do any amazing things at all.

# You canâ€™t change too much at once

If it helps to get some empathy, imagine the life of someone who seriously needs help. An archetype would be the 30-year-old man-child who still lives in his parentsâ€™ basement and plays video games all day.

If you were giving him life advice, it would be something like:

  • Get a job.
  • Fix your diet.
  • Go to the gym every day.
  • Read books.
  • Do a side project.

Can you imagine how they would do that? They canâ€™t do all of these things at once! If you told them to change everything at once, it would be so overwhelming theyâ€™d stay in their old habits. Youâ€™d have more compassion for them and help them make those changes over time.

I can barely fix my diet and go to the gym at the same time, and Iâ€™d like to consider myself a healthily integrated member of society.

Similarly, you should only change one thing at a time. For now, focus on getting to sleep early. Thatâ€™s all.

Slowly increase your productivity as you go. If your goal is to get work done in the morning, start by doing 30 minutes of work, then an hour, and so on.

# Have fun in the morning (when you start)

If thereâ€™s a day you wake up feeling super motivated and ready to do work, then, by all means, do it. But if you donâ€™t feel motivated at the start, just have fun.

I spent around two weeks waking up in the morning and watching TV shows, YouTube or Twitch streams. It was actually fun â€” watching stuff when nobody else was around.

Eventually, I was ready to do work. Trust me, youâ€™ll eventually be ready to do work. Thereâ€™s no way youâ€™re going to wake up every morning to mess around for the rest of your life (if your goal is to be productive); itâ€™ll feel like such a waste.

# ğŸŒ… Choose a Morning Routine

Even after waking up early for months, I still have trouble getting out of bed without my morning routine. I tried to skip it a few times, but it felt wrong â€” as if my morning routine is part of the process of waking up.

A morning routine not only prepares you for the day, but it mesmerizes you. Before my routine, Iâ€™m groggy and tired. After, Iâ€™m excited and awake. Itâ€™s the closest thing to magic Iâ€™ve found.

Itâ€™s like my brain is telling me: â€œnow that youâ€™ve completed the first task of the day, youâ€™re ready to wake up.â€

I journal for my morning routine â€” specifically, I do morning pages. Itâ€™s an exercise from Julia Cameronâ€™s Artistâ€™s Way where you write 3 longhand pages without stopping to think. Itâ€™s designed to unblock artists by teaching them that perfection isnâ€™t necessary to create.

Instead of 3 A4 pages, I do 4 A5 pages. I donâ€™t know if theyâ€™re the same amount, but the exact amount of words you write doesnâ€™t matter. Itâ€™s pretty close though.

I keep a journal and pen next to my bed. Theyâ€™re the first thing I touch (after turning the lights on) after waking up.

# A routine that suits you

You might already have a morning routine or have one in mind you want to try. Or you could also do morning pages.

Here are some other practices I recommend for morning routines:

  • Meditation
  • Yoga
  • Making tea

The actual routine doesnâ€™t matter â€” at least for waking up. Youâ€™ll get different benefits from different routines but the goal is to help you wake up. You want to teach your body what to do when you wake up.

# â° Get an Alarm That Works for You

If thereâ€™s one piece of advice with alarms I would give, itâ€™s this: donâ€™t use an alarm to wake you up; instead, use it as an insurance policy.

When I first started using alarms, I used them to try to cheat sleep. When you use alarms this way, you end up waking up groggy and tired because you didnâ€™t get enough sleep in the first place.

If you donâ€™t want to end up hating your alarm, make sure you set the time to the time after you want to wake up. I set it 8.5 hours after my bedtime and I wake up without it.

# Experiment with alarms

If you havenâ€™t experimented with alarms before, you should. Different alarms suit different people. Do a quick Google search for alarms.

There are all sorts of alarms out there. There are smart alarms, alarms that only work if you step out of your bed, and even phone apps where someone calls you to wake you up. The latter would never work for me, but I can see it working for someone very social.

If you donâ€™t want to do your own research, I have a recommendation for you.

# Try a light alarm

I use a light alarm. A light alarm wakes you up with light before it wakes you up with sound. It starts shining a light 30 minutes before the time you set and slowly gets brighter and brighter. This is useful for early birds because itâ€™s dark early in the morning.

I set it at 5:30 a.m., which means it starts shining at 5 a.m. I never wake up to the sound; I always wake up to the light. It hasnâ€™t been easy to create this habit, but since Iâ€™ve made sure I get enough sleep first, the light is enoughâ€”I never have a jarring sound wake me up.

Hereâ€™s a link to the alarm I use.

# ğŸ“µ Sleep Without Your Phone

If you want a chance at being productive in the morning, you canâ€™t sleep with your phone. Itâ€™s already hard to wake up before everyone else. Donâ€™t make it harder for yourself by giving yourself easy access to addictive stimuli while youâ€™re in bed.

# A boring sleeping environment

Make your sleeping environment as boring as possible. You donâ€™t want to have any excitement before you sleep or after you wake up.

The most common culprit of entertainment in bed is the phone. If you have something else that you love you use in bed like a tablet, I suggest you move that away too.

There are two goals this achieves:

  • Improves sleep
  • Helps with getting out of bed

# No way around it

Before I put my phone in another room, I constantly checked it in bed. I would message my friends. I would check every social media app I had. I would watch YouTube to sleep. I thought it was good because I kept doing it and I was so used to falling asleep with entertainment.

As long as your phone is within reach when you wake up, thereâ€™s an incredible temptation to use it in bed. I donâ€™t know about you but Iâ€™ve stayed in bed for hours mucking around on my phone.

I have no self-control at all, so I control my environment.

# Put your phone in another room

Itâ€™s a simple idea, but not easy. It feels like youâ€™re giving away your baby. But the resistance is good. It means youâ€™re killing an addiction.

Choose a room with a place to charge your phone. This could be the living room, kitchen, or in my case, a study room. Leave your phone there and in the morning, check it after youâ€™ve left your bed, not before.

# ğŸ’Š Use Melatonin as Insurance

Iâ€™ve left the most controversial for last. If you donâ€™t want to take any substances, you can skip this section.

Melatonin is a natural hormone that regulates the sleep-wake cycle. Your body produces it at night to help you sleep. But you can also take it as a pill.

You can get it in the United States without a prescription. Since melatonin is found in some foods, the U.S. Dietary Supplement Health and Education Act of 1994 allows it to be sold as a dietary supplement.

# Dosage

A 2001 study found that the ideal dosage is 0.3 mg. The lowest amount of a melatonin dose Iâ€™ve found is 1mg. If you can find 0.3 mg, then good for you. I use 1mg and cut it into half (0.5 mg). Itâ€™s not exactly 0.3 mg, but it works for me. Iâ€™ve tried different dosages, including up to 10 mg, and none of them worked as well as taking less.

# Regulate your sleep schedule

If you donâ€™t get to sleep on time consistently, melatonin isnâ€™t going to save you. I tried to cheat the system. It didnâ€™t work.

Nevertheless, youâ€™re sometimes going to fail. You might sleep too late. You might have a coffee too late in the day. You might wake up in the afternoon and have trouble sleeping early.

I fail. Iâ€™m not a perfectly disciplined monk. When it happens, I take melatonin.

Even though melatonin isnâ€™t considered an addictive substance, be cautious. Thereâ€™s no evidence melatonin has dangerous effects, but you can build up a tolerance for it.

My recommendation is to use melatonin when you mess up your sleep schedule and canâ€™t get to sleep at your bedtime because youâ€™re too awake â€” but donâ€™t allow that to happen too often.

I said a lot about sleep. Thatâ€™s because most of waking up early is sleeping early, and it isnâ€™t easy to sleep early. There are sacrifices to be made. If youâ€™re willing to make them, you can become an early bird.

There are glamorous parts to waking up early. You get to be productive. You get the feeling of accomplishing something before anybody else does. You get hours of solitude in a solitude-deprived, technology-focused world. I love it.

# äº”å¤§æŒ‘æˆ˜

In this Contest, you can focus on making easy-to-deploy AIoT solutions that can contribute to tackling any of the following Challenges or challenge topics. There are 5 Challenges in total, among which you can freely choose to concentrate on topics of one Challenge or combine several Challenges that are specified in this Contest. Make sure to mention the specific Challenge and challenge topics in your project submission.

Challenge 1: Climate Crisis Prevention/Mitigation

  • Global warming
  • Carbon neutrality
  • Natural disaster prevention/mitigation
  • Sand depletion crisis
  • Environmentally-unsustainable tourism mitigation

Challenge 2: Wildlife/Biodiversity Conservation (Unlimited to various types of flora and fauna)

  • Non-intrusive monitoring of endangered wildlife/biodiversity species from various threats
  • Animal movement, behavior and emotion detection
  • Environmental habitat monitoring
  • Human-wildlife conflict prevention/mitigation

Challenge 3: Marine Conservation

  • Sea level rise
  • Ice and snow melt
  • Marine pollution
  • Harmful algal bloom
  • Plastic pollution

Challenge 4: Open Science

  • Low-cost, open science hardware solutions as scientific research tools designed for outdoor scenarios in the wild (ex. microscopes, science equipment designs, sensors for environmental monitoring, etc.)

Challenge 5: Sustainable Agriculture

  • Climate-smart commodities
  • Precision farming
  • Smart husbandry
  • Autonomous greenhouse
  • Local food production
  • Sustainable food supply chain management

Why 30 is not the new 20

# ä¸­è‹±æ–‡å¯¹ç…§

When I was in my 20s, I saw my very first psychotherapy client. I was a Ph.D. student in clinical psychology at Berkeley. She was a 26-year-old woman named Alex.

è®°å¾—è§æˆ‘ç¬¬ä¸€ä½å¿ƒç†å’¨è¯¢é¡¾å®¢æ—¶ï¼Œæˆ‘æ‰ 20 å¤šå²ã€‚å½“æ—¶æˆ‘æ˜¯ Berkeley ä¸´åºŠå¿ƒç†å­¦åœ¨è¯»åšå£«ç”Ÿã€‚æˆ‘çš„ç¬¬ä¸€ä½é¡¾å®¢æ˜¯åå« Alex çš„å¥³æ€§ï¼Œ26 å²ã€‚

Now Alex walked into her first session wearing jeans and a big slouchy top, and she dropped onto the couch in my office and kicked off her flats and told me she was there to talk about guy problems. Now when I heard this, I was so relieved. My classmate got an arsonist for her first client. (Laughter) And I got a twentysomething who wanted to talk about boys. This I thought I could handle.

ç¬¬ä¸€æ¬¡è§é¢ Alex ç©¿ç€ç‰›ä»”è£¤å’Œå®½æ¾ä¸Šè¡£èµ°è¿›æ¥ï¼Œå¥¹ä¸€ä¸‹å­æ ½è¿›æˆ‘åŠå…¬å®¤çš„æ²™å‘ä¸Šï¼Œè¸¢æ‰è„šä¸Šçš„å¹³åº•é‹ï¼Œè·Ÿæˆ‘è¯´å¥¹æƒ³è°ˆè°ˆç”·ç”Ÿçš„é—®é¢˜ã€‚å½“æ—¶æˆ‘å¬åˆ°è¿™ä¸ªä¹‹åæ¾äº†ä¸€å£æ°”ã€‚å› ä¸ºæˆ‘åŒå­¦çš„ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªé¡¾å®¢æ˜¯çºµç«çŠ¯ï¼Œè€Œæˆ‘çš„é¡¾å®¢å´æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ª 20 å‡ºå¤´æƒ³è°ˆè°ˆç”·ç”Ÿçš„å¥³å­©ã€‚æˆ‘è§‰å¾—æˆ‘å¯ä»¥æå®šã€‚

But I didnâ€™t handle it. With the funny stories that Alex would bring to session, it was easy for me just to nod my head while we kicked the can down the road.

â€œThirtyâ€™s the new 20,â€ Alex would say, and as far as I could tell, she was right. Work happened later, marriage happened later, kids happened later, even death happened later. Twentysomethings like Alex and I had nothing but time.

Alex è¯´ï¼šâ€œ30 å²æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªæ–°çš„ 20 å²â€ã€‚æ²¡é”™ï¼Œæˆ‘å‘Šè¯‰å¥¹ â€œä½ æ˜¯å¯¹çš„â€ã€‚å·¥ä½œè¿˜æ—©ï¼Œç»“å©šè¿˜æ—©ï¼Œç”Ÿå­©å­è¿˜æ—©ï¼Œç”šè‡³æ­»äº¡ä¹Ÿæ—©ç€å‘¢ã€‚åƒ Alex å’Œæˆ‘è¿™æ · 20 å¤šå²çš„äººï¼Œä»€ä¹ˆéƒ½æ²¡æœ‰ä½†æ—¶é—´å¤šçš„æ˜¯ã€‚

But before long, my supervisor pushed me to push Alex about her love life. I pushed back. I said, â€œSure, sheâ€™s dating down, sheâ€™s sleeping with a knucklehead, but itâ€™s not like sheâ€™s going to marry the guy.â€ And then my supervisor said, â€œNot yet, but she might marry the next one. Besides, the best time to work on Alexâ€™s marriage is before she has one.â€

ä½†ä¸ä¹…ä¹‹åï¼Œæˆ‘çš„å¯¼å¸ˆå°±è¦æˆ‘å‘ Alex çš„æ„Ÿæƒ…ç”Ÿæ´»æ–½å‹ã€‚æˆ‘åé©³è¯´ï¼šâ€œå½“ç„¶å¥¹ç°åœ¨æ­£åœ¨å’Œåˆ«äººäº¤å¾€ï¼Œå¥¹ç°åœ¨å’Œä¸€ä¸ªå‚»ç“œç”·ç”Ÿç¡è§‰ï¼Œä½†çœ‹æ ·å­å¥¹ä¸ä¼šå’Œä»–ç»“å©šçš„ã€‚â€ è€Œæˆ‘çš„å¯¼å¸ˆè¯´ï¼šâ€œä¸ç€æ€¥ï¼Œå¥¹ä¹Ÿè®¸ä¼šå’Œä¸‹ä¸€ä¸ªç»“å©šã€‚ä½†ä¿®å¤ Alex å©šå§»çš„æœ€å¥½æ—¶æœŸæ˜¯å¥¹è¿˜æ²¡æ‹¥æœ‰å©šå§»çš„æ—¶æœŸã€‚â€

Thatâ€™s what psychologists call an â€œAha!â€ moment. That was the moment I realized, 30 is not the new 20. Yes, people settle down later than they used to, but that didnâ€™t make Alexâ€™s 20s a developmental downtime.

è¿™å°±æ˜¯å¿ƒç†å­¦å®¶è¯´çš„ â€œé¡¿æ‚Ÿæ—¶åˆ»â€ã€‚æ­£æ˜¯é‚£ä¸ªæ—¶å€™æˆ‘æ„è¯†åˆ°ï¼Œ30 å²ä¸æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªæ–°çš„ 20 å²ã€‚çš„ç¡®ï¼Œå’Œä»¥å‰çš„äººç›¸æ¯”ï¼Œç°åœ¨äººä»¬æ›´æ™šæ‰å®‰å®šä¸‹æ¥ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯è¿™ä¸ä»£è¡¨ Alex å°±èƒ½é•¿æœŸå¤„äº 20 å¤šå²çš„çŠ¶æ€ã€‚

That made Alexâ€™s 20s a developmental sweet spot, and we were sitting there blowing it. That was when I realized that this sort of benign neglect was a real problem, and it had real consequences, not just for Alex and her love life but for the careers and the families and the futures of twentysomethings everywhere.

æ›´æ™šå®‰å®šä¸‹æ¥ï¼Œåº”è¯¥ä½¿ Alex çš„ 20 å¤šå²æˆä¸ºå‘å±•çš„é»„é‡‘æ—¶æ®µï¼Œè€Œæˆ‘ä»¬å´ååœ¨é‚£é‡Œå¿½è§†è¿™ä¸ªå‘å±•çš„æ—¶æœºã€‚ä»é‚£æ—¶èµ·æˆ‘æ„è¯†åˆ°è¿™ç§å–„æ„çš„å¿½è§†ç¡®å®æ˜¯ä¸ªé—®é¢˜ï¼Œå®ƒä¸ä»…ç»™ Alex æœ¬èº«å’Œå¥¹çš„æ„Ÿæƒ…ç”Ÿæ´»å¸¦æ¥ä¸è‰¯åæœï¼Œè€Œä¸”å½±å“åˆ°å¤„ 20 å¤šå²çš„äººçš„äº‹ä¸šã€å®¶åº­å’Œæœªæ¥ã€‚

There are 50 million twentysomethings in the United States right now. Weâ€™re talking about 15 percent of the population, or 100 percent if you consider that no oneâ€™s getting through adulthood without going through their 20s first.

ç°åœ¨åœ¨ç¾å›½ï¼Œ20 å¤šå²çš„äººæœ‰äº”åƒä¸‡ï¼Œä¹Ÿå°±æ˜¯ 15% çš„äººå£ï¼Œæˆ–è€…å¯ä»¥è¯´æ‰€æœ‰äººå£ï¼Œå› ä¸ºæ‰€æœ‰æˆå¹´äººéƒ½è¦ç»å†ä»–ä»¬çš„ 20 å¤šå²ã€‚

Raise your hand if youâ€™re in your 20s. I really want to see some twentysomethings here. Oh, yay! Yâ€™allâ€™s awesome. If you work with twentysomethings, you love a twentysomething, youâ€™re losing sleep over twentysomethings, I want to see â€” Okay. Awesome, twentysomethings really matter.

å¦‚æœä½ ç°åœ¨ 20 å¤šå²ï¼Œè¯·ä¸¾æ‰‹ã€‚æˆ‘å¾ˆæƒ³çœ‹åˆ°æœ‰ 20 å¤šå²çš„äººåœ¨è¿™é‡Œã€‚å“¦ï¼Œå¾ˆå¥½ã€‚å¦‚æœä½ å’Œ 20 å¤šå²çš„äººä¸€èµ·å·¥ä½œï¼Œä½ å–œæ¬¢ 20 å¤šå²çš„äººï¼Œä½ å› ä¸º 20 å¤šå²çš„äººè¾—è½¬éš¾çœ ï¼Œæˆ‘æƒ³çœ‹åˆ°ä½ ä»¬ã€‚å¾ˆæ£’ï¼Œçœ‹æ¥ 20 å¤šå²çš„äººç¡®å®å¾ˆå—é‡è§†ã€‚

So I specialize in twentysomethings because I believe that every single one of those 50 million twentysomethings deserves to know what psychologists, sociologists, neurologists and fertility specialists already know: that claiming your 20s is one of the simplest, yet most transformative, things you can do for work, for love, for your happiness, maybe even for the world.

å› æ­¤æˆ‘ä¸“é—¨ç ”ç©¶ 20 å¤šå²çš„äººï¼Œå› ä¸ºæˆ‘åšä¿¡è¿™äº”åƒä¸‡çš„ 20 å¤šå²çš„äººï¼Œæ¯ä¸€ä¸ªäººéƒ½åº”è¯¥å»äº†è§£é‚£äº›å¿ƒç†å­¦å®¶ã€ç¤¾ä¼šå­¦å®¶ã€ç¥ç»å­¦å®¶å’Œç”Ÿè‚²ä¸“å®¶å·²ç»çŸ¥é“çš„äº‹å®ï¼šä½ çš„ 20 å¤šå²æ˜¯æç®€å•å´æå…·å˜åŒ–çš„æ—¶æœŸä¹‹ä¸€ã€‚ä½  20 å¤šå²çš„æ—¶å…‰å†³å®šäº†ä½ çš„äº‹ä¸šã€çˆ±æƒ…ã€å¹¸ç¦ç”šè‡³æ•´ä¸ªä¸–ç•Œã€‚

This is not my opinion. These are the facts. We know that 80 percent of lifeâ€™s most defining moments take place by age 35. That means that eight out of 10 of the decisions and experiences and â€œAha!â€ moments that make your life what it is will have happened by your mid-30s.

è¿™ä¸æ˜¯æˆ‘çš„çœ‹æ³•ã€‚è¿™äº›æ˜¯äº‹å®ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬çŸ¥é“ 80% å†³å®šä½ ç”Ÿæ´»çš„æ—¶åˆ»å‘ç”Ÿåœ¨ 35 å²ä¹‹å‰ã€‚è¿™å°±æ„å‘³ç€ä½ ç”Ÿæ´»çš„é‡è¦å†³å®šã€ç»å†å’Œçªç„¶çš„é¢†æ‚Ÿï¼Œæœ‰å…«æˆæ˜¯åœ¨ä½  30 å¤šå²ä¹‹å‰å‘ç”Ÿçš„ã€‚

People who are over 40, donâ€™t panic. This crowd is going to be fine, I think. We know that the first 10 years of a career has an exponential impact on how much money youâ€™re going to earn. We know that more than half of Americans are married or are living with or dating their future partner by 30.

é‚£äº›è¶…è¿‡ 40 å²çš„æœ‹å‹ä¸è¦æƒŠæ…Œï¼Œæˆ‘æƒ³è¿™ç¾¤äººä¼šæ²¡äº‹çš„ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬çŸ¥é“èŒä¸šç”Ÿæ¶¯çš„å‰ 10 å¹´å¯¹ä½ å°†æ¥çš„æ”¶å…¥æœ‰é‡å¤§å½±å“ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬çŸ¥é“åˆ°äº† 30 å²çš„æ—¶å€™ï¼Œè¶…è¿‡åŠæ•°çš„ç¾å›½äººä¼šç»“å©šæˆ–è€…å’Œæœªæ¥çš„å¦ä¸€åŠåŒå±…æˆ–è€…çº¦ä¼šã€‚
